skill.name: telnetshell
skill.description: Use telnet to interact with IoT device shells for pentesting operations including device enumeration, vulnerability discovery, credential testing, and post-exploitation. Use when the user needs to interact with network-accessible shells, IoT devices, or telnet services.
skill.summary: Use telnet to interact with IoT device shells for pentesting operations including device enumeration...
skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate IoT penetration testing tool. Static analysis flagged 530 findings as suspicious, but evaluation confirms all are FALSE POSITIVES. The tool explicitly identifies as a pentesting skill and includes authorization requirements. The flagged patterns (password file access, SSH key enumeration, sudoers file access) are standard security enumeration commands used in authorized penetration testing. Risk level is MEDIUM because powerful capabilities require proper user authorization.

content.user_title: Interact with IoT device shells via telnet
content.value_statement: This skill enables secure telnet interaction with IoT device shells for penetration testing. It provides automated device enumeration, security assessment commands, and firmware extraction capabilities for authorized security testing.
actual_capabilities: Execute commands on IoT devices via telnet connection
Run pre-built enumeration scripts for system, network, and security assessment
Automate device discovery and vulnerability identification
Extract firmware from embedded devices via telnet
Monitor telnet sessions in real-time with session logging
Support custom prompt detection for diverse IoT devices
limitations: Requires telnet access to target device (no authentication bypass)
Limited to devices with exposed telnet services
Does not exploit vulnerabilities - only aids authorized assessment

use_cases.title: IoT Security Assessment
use_cases.description: Conduct authorized penetration tests on IoT devices with telnet access for vulnerability research.

use_cases.title: Device Vulnerability Testing
use_cases.description: Assess IoT device security posture for clients using standardized enumeration techniques.

use_cases.title: Internal Device Auditing
use_cases.description: Audit internally deployed IoT devices for security misconfigurations and weak credentials.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Connection
prompt_templates.prompt: Use telnetshell to connect to 192.168.1.100 on port 2222 and run uname -a to identify the device

prompt_templates.title: System Enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the enum_system.txt script against the IoT device at 192.168.1.100 to collect system information

prompt_templates.title: Security Assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Use telnetshell to run the security enumeration script on the device and check for SUID binaries and readable /etc/shadow

prompt_templates.title: Firmware Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use telnetshell to identify MTD partitions on the device and prepare firmware extraction commands

output: Device identified: Linux BusyBox 1.25.0 on armv5tel
Shadow file is NOT readable (good security)
SSH service detected but not running on device

best_practices: Always verify authorization before testing any device - only assess devices you own or have documented permission to test
Use the --logfile flag to enable session monitoring and maintain audit trails of all commands executed
Start with system enumeration before attempting privilege escalation - understand the device before deeper testing
anti_patterns: Never use this skill against targets without explicit authorization - unauthorized access is illegal
Avoid destructive commands that could brick devices - use read-only enumeration when possible
Do not rely on this tool for authentication bypass - it requires valid telnet access credentials

faq.question: Does this skill exploit vulnerabilities?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides telnet interaction and enumeration. Exploitation requires separate tools and techniques.

faq.question: Can this bypass device authentication?
faq.answer: No. Valid credentials are required for telnet access. The tool helps test weak/default credentials only.

faq.question: Is authorization required?
faq.answer: Yes. Always verify you have explicit permission. Unauthorized testing is illegal and unethical.

faq.question: What devices are supported?
faq.answer: Any IoT device with exposed telnet service. Common targets include cameras, routers, and embedded systems.

faq.question: How are sessions monitored?
faq.answer: Use --logfile to save all I/O. Watch sessions in real-time with tail -f in a separate terminal.

faq.question: Can this extract firmware?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill identifies MTD partitions and helps extract firmware for offline analysis on supported devices.
